title: World's Best All Rounder Shakib Al Hassan Slapped With 2-Year Ban For Not Reporting Corruption
text:
World's Best All Rounder Shakib Al Hassan Slapped With 2-Year Ban For Not Reporting Corruption

World's Best All Rounder Shakib Al Hassan Slapped With 2-Year Ban For Not Reporting Corruption

The ICC came down hard on Shakib Al Hasan as it banned him for 2 years for his failure to report corruption related approaches. The ban comes just days after Bangladesh players called off their strike and agreed to tour India.

BREAKING: Bangladesh captain and world No.1 ODI all-rounder Shakib Al Hasan has been banned for two years (one of those suspended), for failing to report corrupt approaches on numerous occasions.https://t.co/depJ2VHSne — ICC (@ICC) October 29, 2019

One year of that ban has been suspended as he agreed to 3 charges of breaching the ICC Anti-Corruption code. This means he will miss next year's IPL and World T20.

The charges are as follows:

Cricinfo

Article 2.4.4 – Failure to disclose to the ACU full details of any approaches or invitations he received to engage in Corrupt Conduct - in relation to the Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe Tri-Series in January 2018 and / or the 2018 IPL

Don't Miss 399 SHARES 13.7 K SHARES 6.8 K SHARES 6.3 K SHARES

Article 2.4.4 – Failure to disclose to the ACU full details of any approaches or invitations he received to engage in Corrupt Conduct - in relation to a second approach in respect of the Tri-Series in January 2018

Article 2.4.4 – Failure to disclose to the ACU full details of any approaches or invitations he received to engage in Corrupt Conduct - in relation to an IPL 2018 match between Sunrisers Hyderabad v Kings XI Punjab on 26 April 2018.

Cricinfo

“I am obviously extremely sad to have been banned from the game I love, but I completely accept my sanction for not reporting the approaches. The ICC ACU is reliant on players to play a central part in the fight against corruption and I didn’t do my duty in this instance," the all-rounder said in a statement.

“Like the majority of players and fans around the world, I want cricket to be a corruption free sport and I am looking forward to working with the ICC ACU team to support their education programme and ensure young players don’t make the same mistake I did,” he added.

This is a setback but he will only have to serve one year and fans will be looking forward to watching him in action once again soon.

With Inputs From Agencies.
